reviewText:
Oh wow, a blast from the past that requires some love.

20 years ago, I thought I was good at RPGs. Then I played Crusaders of the Dark Savant and realized I was good at following the bread crumbs that easy to moderate RPGs lay out for us.

This game was incredibly difficult in the era when there was no gamefaqs.com to download walkthroughs on. When FAQs became a common theme, I re-installed and found it was still pretty tough. That being said, it has a unique world setting, a greatly diverse character class and race structure, and an extensive story-line that is unique and engaging.

Wizardry is not a world for the feint of heart, but for those who embrace a challenge, love RPGs and have an affection for Old School gaming, Crusaders of the Dark Savant is a challenge you must embrace. A stellar game that received far too little fanfare in it's day and is deserving of re-incarnation.

In all fairness, you'd be better off buying the GoG.com version of this one. You get more stuff with GoG.

Play the DOSBOX version if you can because Gold is very crippled by age and does not perform right on Modern machines. For example, the game screen is stuck at a 640x400 size... you can't change it sadly, unless you put the games shortcut in Compatibility mode, and force windows to temporarily resize your desktop resolution down to 640x480. Not a pleasant solution in my opinion.

Other than those gripes, if you're not familar with old school CRPG games, you're going to â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing hate this game, because it is hard. Long. And unforgiving to noobs.  It ain't Final Fantasy. And it ain't Skyrim, scrub.

Here's what not to look forward to:
No automapping- Nope not in this game kid. Back in my day we had to do this â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ with grid paper and draw the maps ourselves. Good luck figuring out where the hell you are in the game. *Psst Gamefaqs got yo back G*

â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ Stat Rolling system for created Characters-  Believe me, you will be doing this alot the first few times or so because the way the game is set up. You get 1 shot for stats per character creation. At the end of character creation, you either accept what you've rolled, or delete it... thus bringing you back to the character review screen where you'll have to go through the entire character creation process. It's an exhausting process,

Thousands of â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ing words! - Hope you enjoy reading sport! Because that's what you'll be doing in this game. No voice acting here. The Gold edition does provide voice narration, but I honestly couldn't deal listening to the guy talk.

The plus to this game is the challenge it presents you. It's a very long dive.. if you do it right it could last you a month or so of game time.

The story is awesome! A mix of sci-fi and low fantasy. It's one of the few CRPGs that tied your party to the previous games. So if you beat Wizardry 6, and imported them into 7, whatever ending you got in 6 carries over into 7. It's pretty cool!

I give this game 7/10 Donut Farts

reviewText:
Make no mistake, this game is a masterpiece.  It's also incredibly difficult.  Use a walkthrough if you ever get stuck (I recommend tk421.net/wizardry/wiz7walk.shtml).

Very very basic tips:

1) Initial party composition should have:
a) 2-3 melee fighter types (Fighter, Valkyrie, Lord, Samurai, Monk, Ninja).  I always recommend Valkyries over Lords as they are functionally the same class, but Valkyries gain levels faster.
b) a defensive caster/healer (Priest or Alchemist)
c) a thief-type (Thief, Bard, or Ranger).  I highly recommend a Bard.
d) an offensive caster (Mage, Psionic, or Alchemist)

2) Save often, and make backups of your saves.  It's easy to irreparably â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ something up in a wway that will make you glad you had a save from 45 minutes prior.  Also, QUIT-NOSAVE if your friend.

3) Many skills gain points on successful use.  Important ones include Skullduggery (gain a point when you successfully pick a lock or disarm a trap) and Ninjitsu (gain a point with every X number of succesful Hide attempts).  Ninjitsu affects your Monk/Ninja's intrinsic defensive ability.

4) Crucial spells to gain access to: Heal Wounds, Cure Lesser Condition, Cure Poison, Identify.  Identify items before equipping/using them whenever possible.

5) Quest items cannot be sold, but they can be dropped.  Do not drop anything unless you're pretty sure you don't need it anymore, and drop used quest items in a safe and easy-to-remember location in case you're wrong.

6) There's a Journey Map Kit in the forest behind your initial spawn location.

7) Explore and enjoy!  The game world is huge and immersive, and the humor is perfectly tongue-in-cheek.

reviewText:
I played the game years ago, but never completed it.  Bought it again so I could finally finish the game. A thoroughly enjoyable, but very difficult, crpg.  The amount of race/class combinations and abilities is astounding.  The puzzles are almost impossible to figure out without the hint book.  Luckily, you get the hint book for free in the program's file folder.  Expect to reload saves often.

I imported a party from Wizardry 6.  One downside is that it took a very long time before I found weapons and armor better than what I had imported with my party from the previous game. So a lot of the early treasure seems a bit worthless.

It takes a long time to finish this game.  Especially if you don't download one of the many save game file editors that are available. Expect to spend years trying to beat the game if you don't use the hint book. Some of the mazes are extremely complicated.

You certainly get a sense of accomplishment when you finally do complete the game.

Recommended if you like Dungeons and Dragons, but want a few more options when leveling your character.  If you liked Eye of the Beholder" or Wizardry 6
date: you'll probably like this as well.  Just keep in mind that the puzzles and mazes are significantly more complicated than "Eye of the Beholder."   Certainly beatable with the use of the hint book."
